metadata.title: Acetylacetonate complexes of vanadium and molybdenum supported on functionalized boehmite nano-particles for the catalytic epoxidation of alkenes

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /ce j
Acetylacetonate complexes of vanadium and molybdenum supported on functionalized boehmite nano-particles for the catalytic epoxidation of alkenes
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2016.09.055 1385-8947/ 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemistry, Shahrood University of Technology, Shahrood, Semnan, Iran. E-mail address: mmirzaee@shahroodut.ac.ir (M. Mirzaee).
Mahdi Mirzaee ⇑, Bahram Bahramian, Jafar Gholizadeh, Abdollah Feizi, Roghayeh Gholami Department of Chemistry, Shahrood University of Technology, Shahrood, Iran
h i g h l i g h t s
Functionalization of BNPs with (OMe)3Si(CH2)3X, X = Cl or NH2. Replacement of the chlorine atom with ethylene di-amine or imidazole. Supporting of Mo and V complexes on functionalized BNPs. Epoxidation of different alkenes using these grafted BNPs catalysts.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
Boehmite nano-particles were prepared via hydrothermal assisted sol-gel processing of aluminium 2- butoxide. The produced powder was covalently functionalized with 3-(tri-methoxysilyl) propylchloride or 3-(tri-methoxysilyl) propylamine and then the terminal chlorine groups were changed by refluxing with ethylenediamine (en) or imidazole (Im). Then all the functionalized boehmite nano-particles were used to support bis-acetylacetonato-oxo vanadium or bis-acetylacetonato-di-oxo molybdenum complexes. These catalysts were applied in epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene and other alkenes. The catalytic procedures with all catalysts were optimized for different parameters such as solvent, oxidant and temperature.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 12 March 2016 Received in revised form 8 September 2016 Accepted 12 September 2016 Available online 12 September 2016
Keywords: Boehmite nano-particles Heterogeneous catalysts Bis-acetylacetonato-di-oxo molybdenum Bis-acetylacetonato-oxo vanadium Alkene epoxidation
a b s t r a c t
Hydrothermal derived boehmite nano-particles (BNPs), with high surface area and high degree of surface hydroxyl groups, were covalently functionalized with 3-(tri-methoxysilyl) propylchloride or 3-(trimethoxysilyl) propylamine and then the terminal chlorine groups were changed by refluxing with ethylenediamine or imidazole. Then all the functionalized boehmite nano-particles were used to support bis-acetylacetonato-oxo vanadium or bis-acetylacetonato-di-oxo molybdenum complexes. These supported catalysts were characterized by FT-IR, CHN, ICP and TEM analysis. Then these catalysts were applied in the epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene, and the catalytic procedures were optimized for different parameters such as the solvent and oxidant. The reactions progress was investigated by gas-liquid chromatography (GLC) analysis. The optimized conditions were found as 0.5 mmol cis-cyclooctene and 1.0 mmol tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) in 0.5–1 mL CCl4 with 20 mg catalyst at reflux temperature. Recycling experiments revealed that these heterogeneous nano-catalysts could be repeatedly applied for the epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene. The optimized conditions were also used for the epoxidation of some other substituted alkenes successfully.
2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Epoxides are known as one of the most valuable precursors for the production of some important chemicals such as chiral pharmaceuticals, pesticides, detergents, epoxy paints, agrochemicals, different polymers, surfactants, antistatic agents, corrosion protection agents, lubricating oils, textiles, sweeteners, cosmetics and perfumes [1–4].
Formerly, some soluble complexes of Cr, Mo, Re, Ni, Co, Mn, V, Cu, Ru and Ti were employed as active homogenous catalysts in epoxidation of alkenes [5–8]. However, most of these catalysts are expensive and contaminate the environment and it is desirable to immobilize them onto insoluble supports. Immobilization can also efficiently increase the reactivity of catalysts by homogeneous dispersion of active metal sites onto the surface of support and/or preventing the formation of oxo-bridged dimeric or polymeric complexes which is deleterious for the catalytic activity [9,10].
Different organic, inorganic and hybrid materials can be used as insoluble supports. Organic insoluble supports include polymers such as poly-styrene [11,12]. Hybrid organic-inorganic materials such as zirconium poly(styrene-phenylvinylphospho nate)-phosphate [13] have been used for this purpose as well. Activated carbon [14], carbon nanotubes [9,15,16], nanostructured ordered carbon material [9,17], porous silica [2,18], MCM-41 [19,3], SBA-15 [9,20–22], zeolites [1,9,23–27], and magnetic nano-particles [28] have been also used as insoluble supports. Inorganic supports generally have higher chemical stability and higher surface area. Also in the most cases, their surfaces were covered with hydroxyl groups which provide valuable sites for the modification with various functionalities. Boehmite (c-AlOOH) is one of these inorganic insoluble supports. Besides its reactivity to catalyze some organic reactions, boehmite was widely used in our research group to anchor different metal complexes covalently, and then used as catalyst in epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene [29,30].
In continuation of our interest to boehmite as an insoluble support, here we used grafted boehmite nano-particles (BNPs) with 3- (Trimethoxysilyl)-propylamine (MSPA) or 3-(Trimethoxysilyl)-pro pylchloride (MSPCl) to anchor ethylenediamine (en) or imidazole (Im). Then they were used to support two complexes of vanadium or molybdenum and employed in epoxidation of different alkene substrates.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text: Solvents and reagents were purchased from Merck or Fluka and used without any further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Rayleigh WQF-500 FTIR instrument at 4 cm 1 resolution, using KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were collected on a Phillips PW-1800 or STOE diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation. Elemental analyses were carried out on a Leco TruSpec CHN Analyzer. Electron microscopy was performed on a JEOL JSM-6360LV transmission electron microscope. Gas-liquid chromatography (GLC) was carried out on a Shimadzu GC-16A instrument using a 2 m column, peaked with silicon DC-200.

sections.heading: 3.1. Preparation of boehmite nano-particles (BNPs)
sections.text:
Aluminium 2-butoxide was synthesized from aluminium and 2- butanol according to the general preparation procedure of aluminium alkoxides [30]. The prepared aluminium alkoxide was hydrothermally hydrolysed, according to our previous report
[29,31], and the produced powder was filtered off and dried at 100 C overnight. Then the produced BNPs were used as catalytic support.

sections.heading: 3.2. Preparation of supported bis-acetylacetonato-oxo vanadium complex on boehmite nano-particles functionalized with ethylenediamine
sections.text:
For the preparation of functionalized BNPs, 1.00 g BNPs was refluxed with MSPCl (400.0 ll, 2.2 mmol) in dry toluene (50.0 ml) for 24 h (Scheme 1). The functionalized BNPs (Cl-BNPs) as a white solid was filtered off, washed three times with dry toluene and dried at 100 C overnight. Then 1.00 g Cl-BNPs was refluxed with en (500.0 ll, 16 mmol) in dry toluene (50.0 ml) for 48 h (Scheme 1) in order to replace the terminal chlorine atoms. During this process, in 6 h intervals, 1.2 ml triethylamine was added to the refluxed solution to ease the replacement of chlorine atom. At the end, en functionalized BNPs (en-BNPs) was filtered off, washed three times with dry toluene and dried at 100 C overnight.
VO(acac)2 complex was then used for supporting on en-BNPs (Scheme 1). For this purpose, 25 ml chloroform was added to VO (acac)2 (0.3 g, 1.1 mmol) and en-BNPs (0.5 g) and the mixture was refluxed for 12 h. Then the mixture was cooled down, filtered off and the precipitate was washed several times with chloroform and dried at 100 C overnight to give V-en-BNPs sample.

sections.heading: 3.3. Preparation of supported bis-acetylacetonato-di-oxo molybdenum complex on boehmite nano-particles functionalized with imidazole
sections.text:
The chlorine functionalized BNPs (Cl-BNPs) was prepared according to the above procedure. Then 1.00 g Cl-BNPs was refluxed with imidazole (138.4 ll, 2.5 mmol) and KI (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) in acetonitrile (30.0 ml) for 48 h (Scheme 1) in order to replace the terminal chlorine atoms. The imidazole functionalized BNPs (Im-BNPs) was then filtered off, washed three times with acetonitrile and dried at 100 C overnight.
MoO2(acac)2 complex was then used for supporting on Im-BNPs (Scheme 1). For this purpose, 15 ml toluene was added to MoO2(acac)2 (0.36 g, 1.1 mmol) and Im-BNPs (0.5 g) and the mixture was refluxed for 6 h. Then the mixture was cooled down, filtered off and the precipitate was washed several times with toluene and dried at 100 C overnight to give Mo-Im-BNPs sample.

sections.heading: 3.4. Preparation of supported bis-acetylacetonato-di-oxo molybdenum complex on boehmite nano-particles functionalized with amine
sections.text:
For the preparation of amine functionalized BNPs, 1.00 g BNPs was refluxed with MSPA (61 ll, 0.35 mmol) in dry toluene (50.0 ml) for 24 h (Scheme 1). The amine functionalized BNPs (A-BNPs) as a white solid was filtered off, washed three times with dry toluene and dried at 100 C overnight.
MoO2(acac)2 complex was then used for supporting on A-BNPs (Scheme 1). For this purpose, 20 ml chloroform was added to MoO2(acac)2 (0.23 g, 0.7 mmol) and A-BNPs (0.5 g) and the mixture was refluxed for 24 h. Then the mixture was cooled down, filtered off and the precipitate was washed several times with chloroform and dried at 100 C overnight to give Mo-A-BNPs sample.

sections.heading: 3.5. Catalytic epoxidation of alkenes
sections.text:
In a typical procedure, a 25 ml round bottom flask, equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar and a condenser, was charged with an alkene (0.5 mmol), an oxidant, the catalyst (V-en-BNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs or Mo-A-BNPs) and solvent, and the mixture was then refluxed. All the reactions were performed at least two times and the reaction progress was monitored by GLC. Since different

alkenes have different reactivity toward oxidation, these reactions were continued until no further progress was observed. The characterization of the main and by-products were performed by comparison of their retention times with standard samples. The alkenes conversion and products selectivity were calculated from peak area by standard addition method. The detailed procedure of the reaction conditions are summarized in Tables 1 and 2.

sections.heading: 3.6. Catalysts recycling
sections.text: In a typical experiment, after recovering the catalyst from the reaction mixture at optimum conditions, it was washed several times with CCl4, and then used in the same procedure under the same conditions. The detailed procedures of the recycling experiment are summarized in Table 3.

sections.heading: 4. Results and discussion
sections.text: Among different methods for the preparation of BNPs, a hydrothermal-assisted sol-gel process on aluminium alkoxide was used here because of its numerous advantages which were reported earlier [29,31]. Then BNPs were grafted with MSPCl or MSPA. The terminal chlorine atoms of MSPCl on grafted BNPs were converted to en or imidazole. Then these functionalized BNPs samples were used to support vanadium or molybdenum complexes in order to investigate the epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene. The catalytic procedures for these catalysts were optimized for different parameters such as catalyst, solvent and oxidant. Then they were used for the catalytic epoxidation of different olefins in optimum conditions. In addition, recycling experiments were done to reveal the reusability of these catalysts.

sections.heading: 4.1. Preparation and characterization of supported vanadium and molybdenum acetylacetonate complexes on functionalized BNPs
sections.text:
BNPs were prepared by hydrothermal assisted sol-gel processing of aluminium 2-butoxide solution in 2-butanol according to the previous reports [29,31]. The IR spectrum of BNPs (Fig. 1a), only shows the characteristic bands of boehmite [31]. The powder XRD pattern of BNPs (Fig. 2a) also confirms crystallization of single phase boehmite [31]. ICP and elemental analysis was also confirmed the lack of molybdenum or vanadium and carbon and nitrogen content in BNPs, respectively. The calculation of particle size from the PXRD pattern according to the Scherer equation shows 10 nm particles for BNPs. This was confirmed by the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of BNPs (Fig. 3). In this image, needle-shaped BNPs are seen over 50 nm long and up to 10 nm width. Efficient surface area of the BNPs is 326 m2/g according to the BET experiment.
BNPs itself has promising catalytic properties for the multicomponent synthesis of substituted imidazole and pyrimidin which were reported elsewhere [32,33]. In addition, it was proved that for efficient epoxidation of olefins in mild conditions, a catalyst which contains an active metal site is vital. Oxidant could coordinate to this site and activated for epoxidation process. But BNPs shows low reactivity in epoxidation of olefins as Choudhary and coworkers reported [34]. Consequently we have been tried to functionalize BNPs with different ligands which our first attempts were published lately [29]. In that reports we have been used Schiff base group for the functionalization of BNPs. Then we have been used it to anchor hexa-carbonyl molybdenum or oxo-sulfate vanadium complexes which successfully applied for the catalytic epoxidation of different alkenes.
In continuation of our efforts to prepare functionalized BNPs, here we have been used 3-(tri-methoxy silyl) propyl chloride

a The amount of metal loadings are 0.66, 0.32, 0.13 (mmol)/g catalyst for V-en-BNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs. b The time of reactions are 60 min for V-en-BNPs and Mo-Im-BNPs and 210 min for Mo-A-BNPs. c The amount of solvent are 1 ml. d Calculated for 0.5 mmol cyclooctene. e GLC yields are based on the starting cyclooctene.
(MSPCl), in order to anchor more complicated amines or other nitrogen contained ligands as functional groups onto the BNPs. Consequently, AO3Si(CH2)3Cl group was grafted on the hydroxyl covered surface of BNPs by refluxing the mixture of BNPs and MSPCl in dry toluene for 24 h (Cl-BNPs, Scheme 1). IR spectrum of Cl-BNPs (Fig. 1b) shows a new band at 2950 cm 1 which assigned to the CAH stretching vibrations of grafted propyl groups in addition to the BNPs characteristic bands. CACl stretching vibration should be shown at 600–650 cm 1, but it probably covered by the sharp vibration of boehmite in this region. Elemental analysis shows that the carbon content of Cl-BNPs was 10.25%, which
means that 2.85 mmol/g of pending groups were covalently bond to the surface of 1.00 g BNPs. ICP analysis shows no molybdenum or vanadium contaminant in Cl-BNPs and it shows no reactivity in catalytic epoxidation of olefins as predictable according to the above discussion. In the second step, pending chorine atoms of Cl-BNPs were changed to en or Im by refluxing the mixture of ClBNPs with en or Im for 48 h (en-BNPs or Im-BNPs, Scheme 1).en has some characteristic vibration bands in the IR spectrum at 3300–3400 and 1070 cm 1 due to the stretching and bending vibrations of NAH, respectively. But, in the IR spectrum of enBNPs (Fig. 1c), all of them probably covered by the sharper bands
of boehmite at the same regions, may be due to the small loading of en groups on the surface of BNPs. Elemental analysis shows that the nitrogen content of en-BNPs was 5.77%, which means that 2.04 mmol/g or near 72% of pending chlorine atoms were changed to en by this reaction. ICP analysis also confirmed the lack of molybdenum or vanadium content in en-BNPs and it showed no reactivity in catalytic epoxidation of alkenes. Then en-BNPs were used for supporting bis-acetylacetonate-oxo-vanadium complex. Therefore, VO(acac)2 was refluxed with en-BNPs in chloroform for 12 h (V-en-BNPs). In addition to the BNPs characteristic bands, IR spectrum of V-en-BNPs (Fig. 1d) shows a new band at 984 cm 1 which is assigned to the V@O stretching vibration of supported complex. ICP analysis shows that the vanadium content of V-enBNPs was 0.66 mmol/g. This means 32% of pending en groups was coordinated to the vanadium complex.
Imidazole also has some characteristic vibration bands in the IR spectrum at 1500–1650 cm 1 due to the stretching vibration of C@C and C@N. In the IR spectrum of Im-BNPs (Fig. 1e), some weak bands were seen in this region. Elemental analysis shows that the nitrogen content of Im-BNPs was 1.01%, which means that
0.36 mmol/g or near 13% of pending chlorine atoms were changed with imidazole by this reaction. ICP analysis also confirmed the lack of molybdenum or vanadium content in Im-BNPs and it showed no reactivity in catalytic epoxidation of alkenes. Then Im-BNPs were used for supporting bis-acetylacetonate-di-oxo-mo lybdenum complex. Accordingly, MoO2(acac)2 was refluxed with Im-BNPs in toluene for 6 h (Mo-Im-BNPs, Scheme 1). Besides the BNPs characteristic bands, IR spectrum of Mo-Im-BNPs (Fig. 1f) shows a new band at 964 cm 1 which is assigned to the Mo@O stretching vibration of supported complex. ICP analysis shows that the molybdenum content of Mo-Im-BNPs was 0.32 mmol/g. This means that over 88% of pending imidazole groups was coordinated to the molybdenum complex.
As comparison, we also used BNPs grafted with MSPA for supporting Mo(O)2(acac)2. Consequently, the mixture of BNPs and MSPA was refluxed in dry toluene for 24 h (A-BNPs, Scheme 1). IR spectrum of A-BNPs (Fig. 1f) shows a new band at 1553 cm 1 which assigned to the NAH stretching vibrations of grafted amine groups in addition to the BNPs characteristic bands. Elemental analysis shows that the nitrogen content of A-BNPs was 0.46%, which means that 0.33 mmol of pending amine groups were covalently bond to the surface of 1.00 g BNPs. ICP analysis also shows any molybdenum or vanadium contaminant in A-BNPs and it shows no reactivity in catalytic epoxidation of olefins. Then ABNPs were used for supporting bis-acetylacetonato-di-oxo-molyb denum complex. Therefore, MoO2(acac)2 was refluxed with ABNPs in chloroform for 24 h (Mo-A-BNPs, Scheme 1). Besides the A-BNPs characteristic bands, IR spectrum of Mo-A-BNPs (Fig. 1h) shows a new band at 948 cm 1 which is assigned to the Mo@O stretching vibration of supported complex. ICP analysis shows that the molybdenum content of Mo-A-BNPs was 0.13 mmol/g. This means that near 40% of pending amine groups was coordinated to the molybdenum complex.
The PXRD pattern of V-en-BNPs (Fig. 2b), Mo-Im-BNPs (Fig. 2c) and Mo-A-BNPs (Fig. 2d) confirms the retention of boehmite crystalline structure after functionalization and metal loading. The calculation of particle size from PXRD patterns of V-en-BNPs, Mo-ImBNPs and Mo-A-BNPs according to the Scherer equation shows no change in particle size in comparison to BNPs.

sections.heading: 4.2. Alkene epoxidation with TBHP catalyzed by V-en-BNPs, Mo-ImBNPs and Mo-A-BNPs
sections.text:
In order to achieve optimize conditions for the title reaction and also the comparison of the results with the previous reports, epoxidation of cyclooctene was investigated by changing different parameters including the solvents, oxidant, catalyst and time. The experiments show that with these catalysts, tertbutylhydroperoxide (TBHP) is the only oxidizing system which can precede the epoxidation of cyclooctene in CCl4. Other oxygen sources such as hydrogen peroxide and urea-hydrogen peroxide in CCl4 or CH3CN does not show any activity (Table 1, entries 10, 12–16, 21, 27–31, 38 and 44–48). We are also used sodium periodate as oxidant but even in the presence of 0.01 g of tetrabutylammonium bromide as the phase-transfer reagent, it does not show any reactivity. In addition, under the mild conditions, the epoxidation of cyclooctene by TBHP did not proceed in the absence of catalyst.
The effect of solvent is the first parameter which was investigated and some protic and aprotic solvents with different polarity and coordinating ability were used in the epoxidation of cyclooctene with TBHP. The observed trend in Table 1, entries 1–7, 21– 27 and 38–44, is the same as literature reports on homogeneous alkene epoxidation by Mo(CO)6 catalyst [35]. Coordinating solvents such as CH3CN and CH3OH compete with TBHP to occupy the coordination sites on transition metal catalyst. Therefore in the
presence of these solvents, the observed yields are too low. Among other solvents, carbon tetrachloride has the highest yield of epoxide product for V-en-BNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs catalysts. This could be attributed to higher boiling point of CCl4 in comparison to others.
As another parameter, the amount of catalysts was changed in the epoxidation of cyclooctene with TBHP. The results on Table 1 (entries 7–11, 32, 36–37 and 51–54) show that increasing the amount of different catalysts up to 20 mg, increased the yield of cyclooctene epoxide.
The ratio of oxidant to substrate is one of the most crucial parameter in catalytic epoxidation processes. The results in Table 1 show that the optimum ratio of oxidant to substrate is 2 for V-enBNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs (entries 10, 17–20, 27, 32–35, 44 and 49–51). Decreasing the ratio from 2, decreased the yields significantly but its increasing did not alter the yield.
Fig. 4 shows the effect of reaction time on epoxidation of cyclooctene with TBHP. Comparing the reactivity of V-en-BNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs catalysts reveals that the first two reach to the maximum yield after 1 h, so they are more reactive than the third which needs 3.5 h to reach this point. This significant difference could be attributed to the lower metal loading on

Mo-A-BNPs (0.13 mmol/g) in comparison with V-en-BNPs (0.66 mmol/g) and Mo-Im-BNPs (0.32 mmol/g). In addition, identical reactivity of V-en-BNPs and Mo-Im-BNPs in contrast to their different metal loading shows the more activity of Mo-Im-BNPs catalyst in the title reaction. This was also confirmed by the previous reports which molybdenum complex was more active than its vanadium counterpart [29].
Moreover, the heterogenic character of these catalysts was checked by the hot filtration test. For this purpose, each catalyst was removed by centrifuging the catalytic mixture in the middle of the optimized process, and the procedure was continued to reach an optimum time of reaction completion. The results obtained showed that when the catalyst was removed from the reaction medium, the catalytic procedure stopped and did not continue anymore. This test proves that the catalytic reactions are held on heterogeneous conditions, and the catalysts are not leached to the reaction medium.
We also investigate the reaction progress of the related homogenous catalysts. The results showed that by use of VO(acac)2 or MoO2(acac)2 as catalyst at the same conditions of heterogeneous V-en-BNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs counterparts, the yields reduced to 81, 85 and 80%, respectively. the heterogeneous catalysts may be related to the homogenous dispersion of catalytic active sites onto the surface of BNPs. This efficiently increased the effective collision of regents to the metal sites in comparison to the homogeneous counterparts and consequently increased the catalytic properties of the cyclooctene epoxidation process.
These new catalysts, V-en-BNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs, can also be used for the epoxidation of a wide range of substituted alkenes (Table 2). Blank experiments, performed without catalysts or with BNPs, en-BNPs, Im-BNPs or A-BNPs, show a very low conversion even after five hours reflux, but in the presence of these catalysts, wide range of both cyclic and linear alkenes could efficiently and selectively convert to epoxides. Based on the epoxidation mechanism suggested earlier [29], higher electron donating ability of olefin double bond is expected to show more epoxidation reactivity. Therefore, cyclooctene and cyclohexene with inner

double bonds should exhibit more activities in comparison to 1- octene and 1-hexene which contain terminal double bonds.
On the basis of Sobczak’s ideas [36] and other experimental and theoretical reports [35,5,37,8] probable mechanisms are proposed for the epoxidation of cyclooctene with TBHP by V-en-BNPs, MoIm-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs catalysts (Schemes 2–4). According to our experimental results, reaction rates displayed first order depending on catalyst and substrate concentrations. There are also some crucial stages in these processes. The first step involves transferring TBHP proton to a terminal oxygen atom of these oxo complexes which was resulted in coordination of tertbutylperoxide anion to Lewis acidic metal centers. Then, olefin substrate coordinated to metal center and, as a nucleophile, inserted to the metal oxygen bond of coordinated peroxide electrophile anion. This mechanism easily explains the faster reaction of electron-rich olefins in comparison to electron-poor olefins. In

ation of olefin with TBHP by Mo-A-BNPs.
the next step, epoxide product was formed and tert-butylperoxide anion was converted into the tert-butoxide anion. Then the peroxide product is released and the catalytic cycle continued by substitution of a new tert-butylperoxide instead of tert-butoxide anion.

sections.heading: 4.3. Catalyst recovery and reuse
sections.text:
As discussed earlier, the reusability of solid supported catalysts is one of their most important benefits. Therefore, the reusability of V-en-BNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs catalysts were monitored by means of multiple sequential epoxidations of cyclooctene with TBHP (Table 3). After each cycle, the reaction mixture was centrifuged and the supernatant solutions and recovered catalysts were analyzed with ICP. This analysis shows that there is no metal contaminant in the supernatant solution and no decrease in metal loading of the recovered catalyst. This also confirmed that metal ions did not leach from the heterogeneous catalysts and the reactions were done entirely in heterogeneous conditions. But after seven cycles recovering of these catalysts, they lose 11–24% of their activities in the epoxidation of olefins. The reason for the gradual decrease in the yields with these heterogeneous catalysts were attributed to the poisoning effect of water vapor which may be adsorbed during recovering process and blocked the catalytic sites on metal center.
In addition, TOF calculation for these catalysts (Table 3, entry 1) shows the order of Mo-Im-BNPs > Mo-A-BNPs > V-en-BNPs. It means that Mo-Im-BNPs catalyst is the most active among them and between V-en-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs, although vanadium contained catalyst takes less time to reach complete conversion of alkene to epoxide but because of the lower metal loading on molybdenum containing catalyst, Mo-A-BNPs has higher TOF.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
We have successfully prepared new hybrid heterogeneous catalysts by anchoring acetylacetonato-oxo vanadium and bisacetylacetonato-di-oxo molybdenum complexes onto the BNPs which are functionalized with en, imidazole or amine. These are active catalysts for the epoxidation of various substituted alkenes under the entirely heterogeneous conditions.
Many molybdenum and vanadium complexes have been reported for the catalytic epoxidation of alkenes with TBHP. However, the catalytic systems which have been prepared in this research are superior to most of the reported catalytic protocols in terms of turn-over frequency (TOF). Very recently, Mohammadikish et al. have been supported the molybdenum complex onto nano-magnetite, and they have been reported a TOF of 19 [28]. Yang et al. have been also supported the molybdenum Schiff base complex onto SBA-15, and they have been reached a TOF of 25 [38]. Moghadam et al. have been reported a TOF of 55.4 for the molybdenum complex supported onto multi-walled carbon nanotubes [39]. All of these reports have lower TOF values than Mo-AFBNPs in the present research. In addition, the TOF values for V-en-BNPs, Mo-Im-BNPs and Mo-A-BNPs (60, 126 and 89 respectively) in the present report are significantly greater than their Schiff-base counterparts, V and Mo-IFBNPs (29 and 44 respectively) in our previous report [29].
There are some crucial factors which considerably change the yields. Among them, type of solvent is the most predominant
and CCl4 as an aprotic, non-polar and hydrophobic solvent, gave the best results.

sections.heading: Acknowledgment
sections.text: The authors would likes to thank the Vice-President’s Office for Research Affairs in Shahrood University of Technology for the financial support of this work.

Besides its reactivity to catalyze some organic reactions, boehmite was widely used in our research group to anchor different metal complexes covalently, and then used as catalyst in epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene [29,30].

Aluminium 2-butoxide was synthesized from aluminium and 2butanol according to the general preparation procedure of aluminium alkoxides [30].
The prepared aluminium alkoxide was hydrothermally hydrolysed, according to our previous report [29,31], and the produced powder was filtered off and dried at 100 C overnight.
The prepared aluminium alkoxide was hydrothermally hydrolysed, according to our previous report [29,31], and the produced powder was filtered off and dried at 100 C overnight.

Among different methods for the preparation of BNPs, a hydrothermal-assisted sol-gel process on aluminium alkoxide was used here because of its numerous advantages which were reported earlier [29,31].

metadata.abstractText: Boehmite nano-particles were prepared via hydrothermal assisted sol-gel processing of aluminium 2butoxide. The produced powder was covalently functionalized with 3-(tri-methoxysilyl) propylchloride or 3-(tri-methoxysilyl) propylamine and then the terminal chlorine groups were changed by refluxing with ethylenediamine (en) or imidazole (Im). Then all the functionalized boehmite nano-particles were used to support bis-acetylacetonato-oxo vanadium or bis-acetylacetonato-di-oxo molybdenum complexes. These catalysts were applied in epoxidation of cis-cyclooctene and other alkenes. The catalytic procedures with all catalysts were optimized for different parameters such as solvent, oxidant and temperature. a r t i c l e i n f o Article history: Received 12 March 2016 Received in revised form 8 September 2016 Accepted 12 September 2016 Available online 12 September 2016
